advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #13</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>New version with Shugart 360 KB formatted capacity floppy drives. Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">North Star has quadrupled the disk capacity of the Horizon computer but prices have increased a modest 15 percent. On a dollar per byte basis, that's a bargain that is hard to beat!...</font><br><br> 1979 prices for assembled versions including 32KB RAM, one parallel and two serial I/O ports:<br> 1 F.D. version: <b>$2565</b><br> 2 F.D. version: <b>$3215</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Really nice advert, we love it.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"French people talking to french people"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to John Kahler for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOGS (1993)</strong></font><br><blockquote>WP-3 model</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil 3: three micro-computers in one!"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPACT VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture; <br><br> <b>Diego Barizo</b> adds:<br> In the picture of the compact version of the TK3000, the joystick, a TRS-80 de luxe joystick, and the screen is quite similar to that of a flight simulator for the TRS-CoCo. Maybe they had one behind the monitor? <p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOL PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><u>Sol Systems price list (january 1977)</u></b> <br><br> (K) = Kit (A) = Assembled<br><br> <b>Sol Terminal Computers<br> </b>SOL-PC Single board (K) <b> $475</b><br> SOL-10 (K) <b> $795</b><br> SOL-20 (K) <b> $995</b> <br><br> <b>Memory Modules</b> <br> PROM Resident Assembly Language (A) <b>$425</b><br> Interpretive Simulator (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Text Editing (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Erasable PROM module (K) <b>$65 </b>(A) <b>$89</b> <br> 4 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b> $159</b> (A) <b> $195</b><br> 8 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b>$295</b> (A) <b>$375</b><br> 16 Kb. Dynamic Ram (A) <b>$529</b> <br><br> <b>Interface Modules</b><br> Parallel / Serial I/O Module (K) <b>$149</b> (A) <b>$199</b><br> System cassette interface (K) <b>$87 </b> (A) <b>$119</b><br> Video Display Module (K) <b>$199 </b> (A) <b>$295</b><br> <br> <b>Mass Storage System</b><br> Helios II Disk system (K) <b>$1895</b> (A) <b>$2295</b><br><br> <b>Software<br> </b>(C) = Cassette (P) = Paper tape<br> Basic 5 (P) <b>$19.95</b><br> 8K Basic (C) <b>$29</b> (P) <b>$37</b><br> New 8080 Focal (C) <b>$14.50</b> <br> Trek 80 Video game (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> GamePack 1 (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> MathPack Video calculator (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> Assembler (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> ALS 8 (C) <b>$35</b> (P) <b>$45</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JUNE 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1986, the Alphatronic PC was bargained in many broker shops for a low price.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEEQUA CHAMELEON BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I did click" <br><br> Cool french young boy, proud of its brand new Adam. Only the expansion module #3 version was available in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This detailed advert presents a complete EXL-100 with all the pripherals available then (printer, disk, tape, modem, carts, etc.). <br><br> "Exelvision, the french micro-computing challenge"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT NOV. 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Compaq has long been recognized as the world leader in both 80386 technology and portable computing. Si it's not surprising that we would combine the two.<br> But no one expected the new Compaq Portable 386 to run at 20 MHz. And no one even dreamed that it would offer 100 MB of storage, disk caching, and much, much more...</font></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Codimex 6809 is a brasilian clone of the Tandy TRS-80 Color Computer.
After the success of another brazilian Coco clone, the Prologica CP-400, several brasilian companies tried to release their own compatible system. The Codimex 6809 is one of them.
It has nothing quite special and doesn't seem to innovate at all... Anyone has more info about this system ?
Source : Computadores Brazileiros
